header_summary:
Jeremy introduces a novel security framework aimed at enhancing the integrity of vault systems through the use of signing oracles, proposing a payment mechanism over time to incentivize honesty and deter malicious behavior. This approach, contrasted with traditional one-time gains from dishonesty, employs private key generation and the possibility of blind signing or homomorphic computations to safeguard against targeted attacks and unauthorized transaction broadcasts, potentially revolutionizing the security of single-party vaults and multisignature setups. [More details](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/30440182-3d70-48c5-a01d-fad3c1e8048en@googlegroups.com/T/#m8423420dacdd1cb73ef8cdf320e3a0351fbd427a)

In an effort to consolidate Bitcoin developers' consensus on covenant proposals, /dev /fd0 has initiated a draft for a Bitcoin wiki page, reminiscent of the SegWit support page strategy. This platform encourages developer participation and insight sharing on opcodes, particularly focusing on OP_CTV for its potential to enhance covenant functionalities like pools and joinstr implementations, thus paving the way for a streamlined process toward the next soft fork. [See the initiative here](https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Covenants_support)

Jungly presents Radpool, a decentralized mining pool architecture allowing miners flexibility in difficulty targets, adjusting dynamically to their hash rates. This novel structure replaces centralized entities with a consortium of Mining Service Providers (MSPs) to maintain a byzantine fault-tolerant database and employ Threshold Signature Schemes for secure payouts, aiming to preserve operational familiarity while boosting security and fairness in reward distribution through a decentralized framework. [Radpool's approach](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/radpool-decentralised-mining-pool-with-futures-contracts-for-payouts/1262/15)

Securitybrahh sparks a debate on cryptocurrency's role as cash, emphasizing Monero's suitability due to its fungibility and privacy, in contrast to Bitcoin's evolving but still questioned fungibility impacted by Taproot and SegWit. This discussion delves into the technical possibilities for Bitcoin's enhancement, like the CTV soft fork and transaction pooling with OP_CAT, underscoring the ongoing discourse within the community on scalability, privacy, and the distinct roles of Bitcoin as "money" and Monero as "cash" for transactions. [Further reading and discussion](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/op-cat-vs-op-ctv-vs-xmr/1303)

active_posts.title: Un-FE’d Covenants: Char-ting a new path to Emulated Covenants via BitVM Integrity Checks
active_posts.summary:
- The email introduces a Bitcoin covenant implementation method using emulators and signing servers.
- Oracle signers must deposit bonds, at risk under a BITVM fraud proof system for rule breaches.
- A detailed paper at [https://rubin.io/bitcoin/2024/11/26/unfed-covenants/](https://rubin.io/bitcoin/2024/11/26/unfed-covenants/) explains the approach without altering the protocol.

active_posts.title: Covenants Support - Bitcoin Wiki
active_posts.summary:
- A new initiative seeks Bitcoin developers' opinions on covenant proposals for a wiki draft.
- The goal is consensus for soft forks, similar to SegWit's approach, inviting more opcode contributions.
- Highlighted is OP_CTV's role in enhancing covenants and pool implementations, urging collective effort for refinement.

active_posts.title: Great Consensus Cleanup Revival
active_posts.summary:
- The analysis proposes improvements to Bitcoin's protocol to enhance security and performance.
- It suggests fixing vulnerabilities like the timewarp exploit and merkle root calculation issues.
- Debate arises over block size reduction, balancing scalability with network efficiency and security.

active_posts.title: Libbitcoin for Core people
active_posts.summary:
- Eric Voskuil showcased Libbitcoin's IBD outperforming Bitcoin Core with up to 15x speed using `-assumevalid`.
- Libbitcoin uses event-based, asynchronous tasks with a relational database structure for efficient block validation.
- Despite lacking full DoS protection and outdated libsecp, Libbitcoin advances in blockchain efficiency and scalability.

active_posts.title: Unspendable keys in descriptors
active_posts.summary:
- Miniscript and taproot integration in Bitcoin Core enhances wallet development possibilities.
- Generating unspendable keys with desired properties for taproot is complex yet crucial.
- Among solutions, using a root xpub with a random chaincode is most practical for hardware signers.

today_in_history_posts.title: A fee-bumping model
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Gloria Zhao credits Darosior and Ariard for their work on improving contract security through fee-bumping.
- She raises concerns about how fee-bumping integrates with the watchtower model and its implications for vault parties.
- Gloria suggests modifications to mitigate RBF pinning and discusses the economic impact on LN service providers and users.

today_in_history_posts.title: PTLCs early draft specification
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The lightning network is discussing PTLC implementation, needing significant transaction and protocol adjustments.
- A proposed minimal-change solution involves new adaptor signatures and pre-signed HTLC-success transactions.
- Changes aim to balance minimizing protocol alterations against reducing additional communication rounds.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin scalability focuses on creating 50,000 off-chain entities for handling transactions.
- Concepts like Utreexo optimize UTXO storage, aiming for a decentralized network of "bitcoin banks."- Ensuring regulatory compliance and operational safety is key for these entities' development and integration.
